name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @bexterc @EndPlasticWaste Then let's find the master key ;-)

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @bexterc @EndPlasticWaste Hi Ben, that is why #WasteManagement is key. But great that there seems to be common ground on the favorable footprint.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @EndPlasticWaste Hi folks, I did not advocate single use, point was that under comparable conditions and systems, #plastic is favorable (also if used for single use) . And: @EndPlasticWaste !! Still reduce, reuse, redesign, recycle is key. Thanks.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @bexterc @EndPlasticWaste Hi Rebecca, maybe I also could not express myself understandable: the article to me suggest "plastic free packaging" as solution and pictures paper boxes. And as you pointed out, that may not be a win to the environment after all.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @SidPlasticWar @EndPlasticWaste No, all about the "plastic free packaging" statement and the picture showing papwr boxes.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @bexterc @EndPlasticWaste No objection! And if e.g. refill, then use most sustainable solution as packaging: #plastic.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @EndPlasticWaste Point is about the wording used and impression created: apples to apples, plastic is the best choice, also as a reusable container (landuse, energy, etc.); showing e.g. paper boxes as (su) alternative and using wording like "plastic free packaging" is misleading. Hope that helps

name: Markus Steilemann
text: It always is very disturbing to see that instead of a better approach to #reduce #reuse #redesign #recycle the focus is on #plastic free. Result: consumers use packaging solutions "guilt-free" that harm the #environnement multiple times more. What a scam. @EndPlasticWaste//t.co/qUa0C02pUt

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @cleanelmbridge @YouTube @Gabriuna @INEOS @TeamINEOS We have a #wastemanagement issue, plastic is not the problem. Parking offenses are not the carmakers fault. So let's @EndPlasticWaste and strive for a @circulareconomy .

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @HughFW Take a reusable glass bottle total footprint compared to a plastic one from cradle to cradle. Energy, water, land use, amount of extracted resources, transportion, etc. . Simple.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @cleanelmbridge @YouTube @Gabriuna I think Tom Crotty has made it very clear: #plastic is not the problem - it is that waste in a linear system is not perceived to have any value. That is why #circulareconomy is the way forward.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @cleanelmbridge @YouTube @Gabriuna I think Tom Crotty has made it very clear: #plastic is not the problem - it is that waste in a linear system is not perceived to have any value. That is why #circulareconomy is the way forward.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @HughFW In a given situation, where packaging is applied, #plastic IS the most sustainable one, if you compare like to like.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: Total ban on plastics 'could damage environment' ! Nothing more to add. @UNEnvironment @EndPlasticWaste @EU_ENV//t.co/ioEysAHY9n

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic There is an ever growing number and I support the general shift towards that. I also have to remain solution and technology neutral. Thanks for your kind understanding.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @2handsproject @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic It is a choice of the way you want to live - humane or medieval. Plastic allows actually to lower by magnitudes the CO2 footprint (also for locally sourced food) AND enables renewables. So cleaner energy and avoidance of energy need. Hard to believe, but that's it.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic There is - besides massive improvement needs in wastemanagement and assesment of packaging needs - thousands right in front of your eyes - if you are willing to embrace the facts available in terms of total life cycle. It is tough to abandone oversimplification.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic It is about less food waste. And there is regions in the world where still 50 % percent of food does not make it from field to fork - imagine the massive CO2 footprint. Part of the solution is packaging. First solution is to accept the complexity.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @cleanelmbridge @wastefighter @Gabriuna @mcquaic @marksandspencer Suggest to focus on waste management. Plastic is seriously part of the solution in many aspects...and yes there is, as with any other material, questionable actions...like bamboo straws. So keep on raising awareness.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic Risk to repeat myself: IF packaging is needed, plastic is the most sustainable. No need, no packaging. Simple. E.g. 98 % plus of the famous packed cucumber CO2 footprint is its production footprint...less than 2% its plastic wrap to massively improve shelf life.less food waste.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic Insufficient focus on mechanical recycling only. Compare all systems like for like (and not just pick at random in each case different criteria), plastics is most sustainable. Check entire life cycle, energy, water, transportation foot print, land use, eutrophication, ...

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic False statement

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic So in case u need packaging (and apples to apples pls), what other material would you suggest and how is the land, water, energy and resource consumption including transportion, eutrophication in this case...btw. you still use a wooden mobile device?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic How does that relate?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @kathrynsheridan @mcquaic To wastefighter Ben: why you just do not stop over here and I give you an idea what and why plastics , also virgin plastic, is sustainable. Be my guest.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin The landfilling and improper #wastemenagenent must stop. The irresponsible ban on plastic either. It often is still the most sustainable option where a material is needed - if this leads to substitution in favor of plastic it may still trigger increase - aiming at closed loop!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @stevensanPH @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV One example on chemcycling is the "Soft landing" in Australia on mattresses and there is plenty more in the entire industry. There is no better or worse. Just case by case. Want to explore more? DM me

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @stevensanPH @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV I believe in creating @circulareconomy . Good enough? No! Good start? Yes. Key is to use the most sustainable material once you know you really need one - eg for packaging, surgery, insulation, electric vehicles etc. Generalizations create inferior solutions.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @stevensanPH @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV @EndPlasticWaste

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @stevensanPH @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV One aim, yet we must not demonize incineration...it is part of the solution.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @stevensanPH @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV It is about reuse and broad options for recycling. That includes incineration and carbon reuse to close the loop. There is not only nails. So we need more tools than just a hammer. Thanks for all you do.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV #Wte opens the way as one of many recycling options to get to higher recycling rates towards a @circulareconomy - mechanical recycling is another but with limitations. And work is going on on usage of carbon from this source to close the loop.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV Energy recovery from waste is a very useful way to avoid extraction of oil that would otherwise be used to produce the energy. Waste to energy is not an invention of the plastic industry.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: The facts are facts regardless of who mentions them. And I am member of the public, too who is informing himself of all sides and simply wants a healthier planet, too. #Plastic contribute, also single use. And to be clear: oceans need to be clean.//t.co/KaBOycJD8p

name: Markus Steilemann
text: It is so important to look at the complete picture: #plastic is the best material to quickly expand #renewables, enable @circulareconomy and save energy (buildings consume 40% globally). It is complex, yes! But it is worthwhile to accept the facts. @EndPlasticWaste//t.co/epNXM0v8dy

name: Markus Steilemann
text: It is so important to look at the complete picture: #plastic is the best material to quickly expand #renewables, enable @circulareconomy and save energy (buildings consume 40% globally). It is complex, yes! But it is worthwhile to accept the facts. @EndPlasticWaste//t.co/epNXM0v8dy

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV @MarineSteph @KingsCollegeLon It works, if you look at light weight mobility, food waste avoidance, fossil free alternatives, net zero buildings, renewable energy production, proper management of ALL waste and use the least energy consuming material in a given context - AND tackle the current issues. DM me

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry Close the loop then.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @aplastic_planet Even an increase may be helpful as long as we keep it in the loop and it saves other resources. Single use where needed is best done in #plastic. Compostable would be part of the solution. That includes to go beyond mechanical recycling @EndPlasticWaste .

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV @MarineSteph @KingsCollegeLon I follow a broad range of different science and take a broad view. That results in commitment to @EndPlasticWaste , @circulareconomy and an unbiased view on the value and #sustainability of #plastic . @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV Thanks for all you do in this context.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @lizbonnin @aplastic_planet @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV @MarineSteph @KingsCollegeLon I follow a broad range of different science and take a broad view. name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry I know you are very much in leasing, which is one of the potential solutions - amongst many others. On your attribution on strategy and intention of the industry - I guess you need an update. Thanks for the great conversation.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry I am a great fan of reusable packaging! And if you compare for reusable systems different materials, #plastic again makes most sense. Thanks for bringing this up.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @2handsproject @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV Depends on what u do with the off gas ! Use the CO2!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG @AmChemistry Enjoy your we-strawberries then - and the facts: #plastic saves energy, lifes, resources, food and more - AND we need to solve the #wastemanagement topic. Some inspiration: @AmChemistry @circulareconomy @EndPlasticWaste @UNEnvironment @EU_ENV Thanks for the great conversation.

text: @aplastic_planet @lizbonnin @EndPlasticWaste @BCG Amongst others @AmChemistry study shows lifecycle benefits of #plastics compared to metal, paper, glass. text: @shorethingG82 @covestro @EndPlasticWaste Yes, and this is the challenge that needs to be solved. This is what @EndPlasticWaste is about amongst others. It is rough and rocky as it involves entire value chains, policy, and consumers. and it involves clean up. I bothers me as it bothers you.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @petemyers Since when is the size of an association correlated to the strength of a scientific evidence. Science history suggests that the opposite often holds true and consensus is not a scientific approach. Remind me: how many EDs naturally occure in a tomato?

text: @leotrasande @rebecca_altman @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall @TheEndoSociety @WHO @UNEnvironment @TheLancetEndo @EUparliament It is important to stay with advancements in science and that is well reflected and hence i cannot really follow where you see any dismissive action. The particular substance you mentioned is assessed to be safe.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @rebecca_altman @leotrasande @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall Nice alegorie yet it does not change the overall very neat and dilligent work and long term review of hundreds of scientific papers. In your recent reply on plastics the cited study was funded by the EPA - it is obviously an authority.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @leotrasande @rebecca_altman @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall @TheEndoSociety @WHO @UNEnvironment @TheLancetEndo Believe me I did and that is why I am convinced that on the substance you particularly talked about the respectice agencies did a thorough and diligent job. I have kids, too.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: Endlich gibt es erste Anzeichen fr eine breite Wahrnehmung von Wasserstoff als zentralem Energietrger auch fr den Transport- & Verkehrssektor. Danke @handelsblatt @KaWitsch//t.co/BTX4BD7hVH

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @leotrasande @rebecca_altman @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall Unfortubately I have to disagree as the mentioned substance is one of the best researched in the world and leading agencies have repeatedly stated the safety in its intended use. Over 50 years.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @rebecca_altman @leotrasande @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall Rebecca, any (!) other material under practical societal circumstances has a more negative impact for most discussed purposes. Use the carbon we have already extracted is possible...lighter, more sustainable and more efficient to net zero ...only with plastics. #circulareconomy

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @rebecca_altman @leotrasande @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall Which is actually a preoccupatiom from the past and also an often met yet simply false generalization, not considering the massive progress. True sustainability and progress will only be achieved by and through chemistry at all levels of a circular economy...with #plastic

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @rebecca_altman @leotrasande @petemyers @MariahCBlake @j_g_allen @MrMikeNewall Hi Rebecca, that is a great read and fully supports my statement, in particular in comparison to metal, paper, and glass. A more sustainable society without high tech materials - and yes also wisely used single use- will not work. Tha ks for sharing! #CircularEconomy #plastic

text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Leider erschliet sich auch hier wieder nicht die Faktengrundlage und der Zusammenhang.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Leider erschliet sich Ihre Logik nicht und stigmatisierende Anwrfe ndern das auch nicht. Es gibt ein generelles Abfallthema, das gilt es zu lsen. Das ndert aber nichts am positiven Beitrag, den Kunststoffe fr nachhaltige Lebensweisen leisten.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Da muss ich Ihnen leider widersprechen. Kunststoffe, auch solche die CO2 als Rohstoffbasis nutzen, sind Teil der Lsung. Wurde auch wissenschaftlich in Lebenszyklusanalysen bewiesen. Was Indien glaubt ist mir leider nicht bekannt. Wissen Sie mehr?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Wenn Sie mir einmal den Zusammenhang zwischen freier, sehr faktenbasierter Meinung eines echten Journalisten und Ihren erneut nicht untermauerten und dennoch uerst schwerwiegenden Anwrfen erlutern, wre ich Ihnen dankbar.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @PatrickBernau @karsten_dirk @faznet So ist es!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Kann den Bezug zwischen eindeutigen, aber sicher bestimmte Ideologien herausfordernde Fakten und Ihren Anwrfen leider nicht herstellen. Bin daher beruhigt, dass Ihnen das gelingt. So werden Lsungen geschaffen - sehr berzeugend.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @woksoll @PatrickBernau @chemieverband Danke fr diese sehr differenzierte und besonders lsungsorientierte Sachkritik.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @PatrickBernau @vlkr Grossartig! Es scheint leider so zu sein, dass es Fakten schwer haben gegen Ideologie.

text: @wastefighter @endlessyaffle @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Ben, you are right! When in general conversations recycling is mentioned it means "mechanical recycling" That has its limitations. Yet there is other means: chemolysis, pyrolysis and incineration with off gas usage and rebuild from scratch. #renewable #carbon

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @endlessyaffle @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Ben, you are right! When in general conversations recycling is mentioned it means "mechanical recycling" That has its limitations. text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Dear Sir, sorry to disagree also here: they can be fully recycled and the production requires up to 4 times less the energy than the next best material alternative. #renewable #carbon #circulareconomy #plastic #climatechange #SDGs

text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter Dear Sir, I am very well aware of the plastic waste and as I said this needs to be tackled and will be tackled. It does not change the overwhelming benefits I mentioned. The picture is disturbing and requires action - a #sustainable #future with #plastic is part of the solution.

text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter Dear Sir, I am very well aware of the plastic waste and as I said this needs to be tackled and will be tackled. It does not change the overwhelming benefits I mentioned. The picture is disturbing and requires action - a #sustainable #future with #plastic is part of the solution.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @endlessyaffle I see your point Ben and I do agree that there is few wrong developments. Overall it does not change the essential benefits eg for better food preservation and hence lower footprint in the grand scheme.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko My apologies sir to disagree, but banning one of the best and most #sustainable #materials that eg preserve food, safe energy, enable renewable energy production, life saving medical equipement and so much more is the wrong step. #circulareconomy is the solution.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko My apologies sir to disagree, but banning one of the best and most #sustainable #materials that eg preserve food, safe energy, enable renewable energy production, life saving medical equipement and so much more is the wrong step. #circulareconomy is the solution.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko I see your point and that is why waste management and right material selection and management are of utmost importance. #plastics #SDGs #circulareconomy . On the topics you mentioned: let's tackle it.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @endlessyaffle @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko I see your point and that is why waste management and right material selection and management are of utmost importance. #plastics #SDGs #circulareconomy . On the topics you mentioned: let's tackle it.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: Cefic DG @Mmens is at the SAICM (@ChemandWaste ) regional meeting for EU-JUSSCANNZ today, talking about the EU industry's role in implementing International #Chemicals Management beyond 2020. #CircularEconomy #WasteManagement//t.co/aYvNn6DOf1

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko That is the discussion we need: when dies single use make sense, then discuss the material, and in all cases manage the waste as valuable raw materials.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Hi Darryl, it is, as mechanical recycling is only one of many: chemolysis, pyrolysis, and molecular recycling (done with glass btw) are most energy efficient and very effective applied to plastics. So most #sustainable , considering all aspects. It is complex, I admit.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Very simple: if a single use item is necessary, then pyrolysis, chemolysis, mechanical recycling, or renewable carbon work best and at lowest energy with #plastics. It is for single use and for reuse still most effective, also for #circulareconomy .

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Very simple: if a single use item is necessary, then pyrolysis, chemolysis, mechanical recycling, or renewable carbon work best and at lowest energy with #plastics. It is for single use and for reuse still most effective, also for #circulareconomy .

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko I would argue that single use plastic for the right application is the best material solution: the ever growing demand of renewable energy to enable a #circulareconomy needs low energy materials. Same applies for reuse. Proper waste management is the challange for all materials.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Darryl_Annison @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko True, that is the waste management issue to be tackled. Plastic requires low amount of energy to access the raw materials, produce it, transport it (much lower weight), re-feed it after use. So, overall the footprint is comparably lower = more sustainable. It's complex, I admit

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @ClaireRiley9 @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko @Chillysbottles Sure, there is an acc study. I will forward you the link, just have to search for it.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @ClaireRiley9 @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko @Chillysbottles Yes, really.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @ClaireRiley9 @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko @Chillysbottles Hi Claire, apologies if I may disagree. Reusable plastic bottles are amongst THE most sustainable solutions amongst all reusables. Raw materials, water, energy, land use, etc. turn out to be in favor. And that spreads from sourcing to logistics to wastr management.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter That is what is truely missing these days: a conversation with respect, even where there may be strong disagreement. Let's find the best ways forward - jointly!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Also understood. If you take this approach, there is way more concerns about the total footprint (water, land, eutrophy, CO2) of most alternative fibers, also natural ones. It is so important to look at the great scheme.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko On Fibers: we need to look at the whole circle again and see how we capture "washed out" ones...and at the risk of being hammered: no health issues proven (though many assumed ones).

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko That catchy phrase is often used because there is less evidence...this is the huge challenge of our times: catchy phrases and emotionally supercharged pictures fuel ideology - and replace a real solution oriented debate. We have a waste crisis, not a plastic crisis

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @KeepBritainTidy @LoveWilko Hi Ben, agree. The challenge remains: what is the definition of entirely unnecessary? And when it is necessary #plastics remain the best choice from an overall lifecycle view. I know it feels disturbing, but it is the case.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @6esm Very disturbing words...

text: @BrillantBy @mduchenski @mpeer @handelsblatt @covestro @FAO Gerade am Samstagmorgen zurckgekehrt und wir setzen mit Partnern genau bei den Kleinbauern an.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @BrillantBy @mpeer @handelsblatt @covestro Das ist sicher ein valider Punkt. Wenn also die Bauern durch Khlkette und Konservierung mehr Einnahmen aus der gleichen Feldbewirtschaftung erzielen, ist das doch ein guter Anfang.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @BrillantBy @mpeer @handelsblatt @covestro Auch hier wage ich zu widersprechen: solange Nahrungsmittel verderben und Mangel herrscht, ist Khlung und Konservierung essentiell; und der Nhrwertverlust bei guter Khlung ist wirklich gering.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @BrillantBy @mpeer @handelsblatt @covestro Ich sehe Ihren Punkt und muss hier widersprechen: ohne Khlkette und weitere Manahmen schaffen es fast die Hlfte aller produzierten Feldfrchte nicht zum Verbraucher. Hier setzen wir mit den Erzeugern und Partnern an - ohne Qualittsverlust, wie ich mich selber versichert habe.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter There is chemolysis, pyrolysis, gasification and incineration (for the latter it is important to embedd this into a closed loop of off-gas usage like "carbon to chemicals") . Sorry for being a bit technical.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter @apeasbrain Again, only mechanical recycling is looked at in this article hence a very narrow view. There is more options.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @apeasbrain @wastefighter Yes, this is true for so many materials , if you only consider mechanical recycling. But there is additional options!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @apeasbrain @wastefighter Do it like nature does: break it down to its smallest parts and then rebuild it..and it works.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @apeasbrain @wastefighter The carbon footprint effect is well researched, as attached in the original tweet. And you are right: aim is to use the right material choice for the right use!

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @wastefighter It is very realistic! And also necessary to keep the oceans free from plastic! As you are refering in your examples to mechanical recycling only, it is important to also consider additional existing recycling methods.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @PieterdeJong_EU @SusChem Currently there is no consumer study that suggest clearly how we can make plastic waste being perceived to have a value - big challenge. Beach clean up is important yet overall not the largest challenge. And there must be no difference between bio- or fossile- based plastics.

text: @juliaBXL Sehr guter Ansatz der sicher auch fr viele weitere Lebensmittel aus der versorgungssicheren Landwirtschaft angewendet werden kann.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Vielen Dank, das hilft mir besser zu verstehen, wie das Thema wirklich angegangen wird. Dann hoffe ich, dass auch bei Ihnen im Haus Fakten die Oberhand behalten. Alles Gute auf dem Weg.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Ereichen Sie bei allen Netzen in der Praxis diese Umlaufquote? Und wieviel Prozent der Menge aler Kunststoffe im Verkauf bei Ihnen sind durch diese Lsungen nachhaltiger ersetzt? Ich nutze Kunststofffaltboxen, daher kein Netz.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: 8 Mio tons every year (estimate!) are 8 Mio tons too much. So let us continue to aim for #circulareconomy and use valuable #plastic as raw material for new valuable materials - also for the other 267 mio tons. @SDGoals @wef//t.co/CFyp3BMbd5

name: Markus Steilemann
text: 8 Mio tons every year (estimate!) are 8 Mio tons too much. So let us continue to aim for #circulareconomy and use valuable #plastic as raw material for new valuable materials - also for the other 267 mio tons. @SDGoals @wef//t.co/CFyp3BMbd5

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Ich denke an Getrnkeflaschen einerseits und die in der Praxis tatschlich gelebte Umlaufquote der Frischenetze. Diese ist essentiell um wirklich nachhaltiger zu sein als ultradnne Kunststofffrischebeutel. Ab welcher Umlaufquote lohnt sich das Ihren Berechnungen nach?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Sehr gut und Danke dafr. Dass das gegenber Holz und rezykliertem Papier eine Verbesserung bringt ist nachvollziehbar. Den Vergleich gegenber extrem effizientem Kunststoff konnte ich dort nicht finden. Wie werden die Schalen dann in den Kreislauf zurckgefhrt in der Praxis?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Grossartig, dafr sind bereits jetzt umfangreiche Lsungen aus superleichten Kunststoffen im Einsatz, die bei Herstellung und Transport relativ gesehen viel weniger Energie verbrauchen als Ersatzmaterialien - mit gleichen Mehrfachverwendungsraten. Also wirklich nachhaltiger.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Und wie bewerten Sie das? Wie kommt das Gras als Rohstoff von der Wiese fr das Papier als Verpackung zum Lebensmittel - und vom Verbraucher (in der Praxis) zurck in die Natur um dem Kreislauf zu schlieen? Und wieviel Wasser und CO2 werden relativ eingespart zu Kunststoff?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @juliaBXL Jetzt haben Sie mich neugierig gemacht: welche Verpackungen sind denn noch umweltfreundlicher als Kunststoffverpackungen?

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Kikomatthews @youngmark1 @ArrunGB @McDonaldsUK There is an urgent need to reduce, reuse, recycle, and recover - never in doubt about that and I am in. The conversation here refers to replace.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @Kikomatthews @youngmark1 @ArrunGB @McDonaldsUK It is important in this context that there is no reduce but replace (see announcement). Hence here the material with overall least impact is to be chosen, which requires to get to the roots and wholistically see the context...hence exactly not being greedy or lazy.

name: Markus Steilemann
text: Thanks @K_McGovern_ for sharing this. A huge challenge, but completely worth aiming for it. #pushingboundaries//t.co/jgbXXYlPt9

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @youngmark1 @ArrunGB @McDonaldsUK Effective recycling is key for any material used e.g. in straws, incl. paper and natural, hence anyhow a task to be completed that doesn't go away, non-fossile sources for plastic are available and the energy to harvest, make, distribute other materials is mainly fossile...

name: Markus Steilemann
text: @youngmark1 @ArrunGB @McDonaldsUK And what about the situation that the collection and recycling closes the loop towards circularity while at the same time saves tremendous amount of fossile fuels... any alternative straw material consumes significant amounts of energy to be produced...incl. real straws.

text: @youngmark1 @ArrunGB @McDonaldsUK Any comprehensive and open source facts at hand that objectively prove the betterment through bans? Or just continue disregard human beings with different views?
